title: CSS Icons
subject: CSS
learning_objectives: Understand how to use icon libraries
theory:
The simplest way to add icons to your HTML page is with an icon library, such as Font Awesome, Bootstrap Icons, or Google Icons.

Since these icons are essentially vectors or fonts, you can customize them with CSS (size, color, shadow, etc.) just like text.

examples.output: Displays a large red car icon.
examples.explanation: Icons scale without losing quality because they are vectors.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using image tags for simple icons
common_mistakes.correction: Use icon fonts or SVGs for scalability and performance.

interview_questions.question: Why are icon fonts/SVGs better than raster images?
interview_questions.answer: They are scalable (no blurriness on zoom), smaller in file size, and can be styled with CSS color/size properties.

practice_problems.problem: Include the Google Material Icons library.
practice_problems.hint: Use a link tag pointing to Google Fonts API.

real_world_use_cases.description: User interfaces rely on icons (Trash can for delete, Pencil for edit) to save space and convey meaning quickly.

exam_notes: Most icon libraries use the <i> or <span> tag.
Icons inherit the text color of their parent.
summary: Icons improve user experience by providing visual cues. CSS allows you to seamlessly integrate them into your design.
